articles.headline: Jan. 6 Panel Accuses Trump of Insurrection and Refers Him to Justice Dept.
articles.snippet: The committee also accused the former president of three other federal crimes, including conspiracy to defraud the United States. Five Trump allies were referred as well.
articles.abstract: The committee also accused the former president of three other federal crimes, including conspiracy to defraud the United States. Five Trump allies were referred as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol accused former President Donald J. Trump on Monday of inciting insurrection, conspiracy to defraud the United States, obstruction of an act of Congress and one other federal crime as it referred him to the Justice Department for potential prosecution.

articles.headline: Pope Francis to Return 3 Parthenon Marble Fragments to Greece
articles.snippet: The pope will donate the 2,500-year-old pieces held by the Vatican Museums to the archbishop of Athens, a gesture that increases pressure on the British Museum to act over similar items on show in London.
articles.abstract: The pope will donate the 2,500-year-old pieces held by the Vatican Museums to the archbishop of Athens, a gesture that increases pressure on the British Museum to act over similar items on show in London.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pope Francis will return to Greek hands three 2,500-year-old pieces of the Parthenon that have been in the papal collections of the Vatican Museums for two centuries, the Vatican said in a statement on Friday.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Alex Marshall

articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Said to Agree to Extradition After Chaotic Hearing
articles.snippet: The disgraced FTX founder, who has been in a Bahamas prison for the past week, agreed to be sent to the United States, after a confusing day in court.
articles.abstract: The disgraced FTX founder, who has been in a Bahamas prison for the past week, agreed to be sent to the United States, after a confusing day in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disgraced cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried has agreed to be extradited to the United States, one of his lawyers said on Monday, after a chaotic morning of legal maneuvering in which Mr. Bankman-Fried was shunted back and forth between court and prison in the Bahamas.
articles.byline: By Royston Jones Jr., David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: One Governor’s Border Wall Is Another Governor’s Headache
articles.snippet: Doug Ducey, the outgoing governor of Arizona, spent $82 million to stack shipping containers along the border with Mexico. His successor, Katie Hobbs, calls it a waste of money.
articles.abstract: Doug Ducey, the outgoing governor of Arizona, spent $82 million to stack shipping containers along the border with Mexico. His successor, Katie Hobbs, calls it a waste of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S./MEXICO BORDER, Ariz. — Andy Wrenn could not believe all the trucks. Every morning starting this fall, a herd of pickups rumbled past his home in the Huachuca Mountains near Arizona’s southern border, hauling shipping containers to a grassland populated mostly by songbirds and mule deer.

articles.headline: Los Angeles Jury Finds Harvey Weinstein Guilty of Rape in Mixed Verdict
articles.snippet: The former film producer was convicted of sex crimes for the second time, though the jury could not reach a decision on three counts and acquitted him on one count.
articles.abstract: The former film producer was convicted of sex crimes for the second time, though the jury could not reach a decision on three counts and acquitted him on one count.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harvey Weinstein, once a film colossus who wielded immense power in Hollywood, was found guilty on Monday of raping and sexually assaulting an actress in 2013, but jurors found him not guilty of one charge and could not decide on three other counts.
articles.byline: By Lauren Herstik, Jill Cowan and Livia Albeck-Ripka

articles.headline: A Diminished Trump Meets a Damning Narrative
articles.snippet: Former President Donald Trump’s current woes extend beyond the report by the House Jan. 6 committee, but the case the panel laid out against him further complicates his future.
articles.abstract: Former President Donald Trump’s current woes extend beyond the report by the House Jan. 6 committee, but the case the panel laid out against him further complicates his future.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the summer and the House Jan. 6 committee’s hearings began, former President Donald J. Trump was still a towering figure in Republican politics, able to pick winners in primary contests and force candidates to submit to a litmus test of denialism about his loss in the 2020 election.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Advance Sprawling Spending Bill in Race to Avoid Shutdown
articles.snippet: The legislation, which would fund the government through September, would significantly increase federal spending and provide billions of dollars in emergency aid.
articles.abstract: The legislation, which would fund the government through September, would significantly increase federal spending and provide billions of dollars in emergency aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday advanced a sprawling spending package that would keep the government open through next fall after senior lawmakers from both parties reached a compromise on billions of dollars in federal spending, including another round of emergency aid to Ukraine.

articles.headline: One Day With an Ambulance in Britain: Long Waits, Rising Frustration
articles.snippet: Britain is experiencing a crisis in ambulance response times, part of a broader breakdown in the country’s revered National Health Service. We rode with one crew to witness the problems in real time.
articles.abstract: Britain is experiencing a crisis in ambulance response times, part of a broader breakdown in the country’s revered National Health Service. We rode with one crew to witness the problems in real time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WREXHAM, Wales — Rachel Parry and Wayne Jones, two paramedics with the Wrexham Ambulance Service, pulled up to a hospital in northern Wales with a patient just after 10 a.m. one early December morning.

articles.headline: Clean Energy Quest Pits Google Against Utilities
articles.snippet: Google says its goals for carbon-free power are impeded by state-regulated utilities, particularly in the Southeast, that lack a competitive market.
articles.abstract: Google says its goals for carbon-free power are impeded by state-regulated utilities, particularly in the Southeast, that lack a competitive market.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the sort of dry panel discussion that occurs at hundreds of industry conferences every year — until a Google representative decided it was time to unleash.

articles.headline: In Public Schools, the N.R.A. Gets a Boost From Junior R.O.T.C.
articles.snippet: Instructors in military-sponsored J.R.O.T.C. classes have offered to promote the N.R.A. in high schools in exchange for money for their marksmanship programs.
articles.abstract: Instructors in military-sponsored J.R.O.T.C. classes have offered to promote the N.R.A. in high schools in exchange for money for their marksmanship programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE CORAL, Fla. — Beneath the fluorescent lights of a high school gym, dozens of teenagers took turns firing air rifles at a series of bull's-eye targets, part of a marksmanship competition that drew students from schools all along the Florida Gulf Coast.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Wells Fargo to Pay $3.7 Billion Over Consumer Banking Violations
articles.snippet: The settlement, which includes the largest fine ever imposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, allows the bank to resolve claims that it had harmed millions of consumers since 2011.
articles.abstract: The settlement, which includes the largest fine ever imposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, allows the bank to resolve claims that it had harmed millions of consumers since 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo’s yearslong mistreatment of its customers has resulted in another record-breaking fine and a warning that more restrictions on its ability to do business could soon follow.
